children.text:
Now, in Fortran, the subroutine would need to be declared as recursive. So the code outline:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, q
    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:), c(:), d(:)
    integer(8) :: ans = -100_8
    integer, allocatable :: list(:)
    integer :: i

    read *, n, m, q
    allocate(a(q), b(q), c(q), d(q)) do i = 1, q
        read *, a(i), b(i), c(i), d(i)
        a(i) = a(i) - 1
        b(i) = b(i) - 1
    end do

    allocate(list(n)) call dfs(list, 0)
    print *, ans

contains

    recursive subroutine dfs(list, k)
        integer, intent(inout) :: list(n)
        integer, intent(in) :: k
        integer(8) :: score
        integer :: next_num, start_num, i

        if (k == n) then
            score = 0_8 do i = 1, q
                if (list(b(i)+1) - list(a(i)+1) == c(i)) then
                    score = score + d(i)
                end if
            end do
            if (score > ans) then
                ans = score
            end if
            return
        end if

        if (k == 0) then
            start_num = 1
        else
            start_num = list(k)
        end if

        do next_num = start_num, m
            list(k+1) = next_num
            call dfs(list, k+1)
        end do
    end subroutine
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
dfs

end program main

subroutine dfs(list, k)
    integer, intent(inout) :: list(n)
    integer, intent(in) :: k
    integer :: next_num, i

    if (k == n) then
        ! compute score
        call compute_score(list)
        return
    end if

    if (k == 0) then
        start_num = 1
    else
        start_num = list(k)
    end if

    do next_num = start_num, m
        list(k+1) = next_num
        call dfs(list, k+1)
    end do
end subroutine

Wait, but in the Java code, the list is built incrementally. So when the list is empty (k=0), the first element can be 1 to m. Then each subsequent element is >= the previous.

So in the Fortran code, the initial call is with list being an array of n elements, but k=0. So the first element is placed in position 1 (since k+1 = 1).

But in Fortran, array indices start at 1. So the list is list(1), list(2), ..., list(n).

So the initial call would be to dfs(list, 0), and then in the first iteration, k=0, start_num is 1, loop from 1 to m, setting list(1) to next_num, then call dfs with k=1.

Then, when k=1, start_num is list(1), loop from list(1) to m, set list(2), etc.

So the sum is computed correctly.

The maximum sum is tracked in a variable ans, which is initialized to -100 (since the Java code uses ans = -100L, but in Fortran, integers are 32-bit by default, but the problem may require larger numbers. Wait, the Java code uses 'long' for ans and score. So in Fortran, we need to use integer of kind 8 to handle large integers. Because if q is up to 50 and d[i] is up to 1e5, then the sum can be up to 5e6, which is within 32-bit integer. But in Java, 'long' is 64-bit. So to be safe, in Fortran, use integer(kind=8) for ans, sum, etc.

So in Fortran, declare ans as integer(8) :: ans = -100_8.

Now, the code structure:

- Read n, m, q.

- Allocate arrays a, b, c, d with size q.

- Read each of the q lines into a, b, c, d, then adjust a and b by subtracting 1.

- Call the dfs subroutine to generate all possible sequences.

- After dfs returns, print ans.

The main challenge is implementing the dfs in Fortran with recursion, handling the list correctly.

Now, in Fortran, the subroutine would need to be declared as recursive.

So the code outline:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, q
    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:), c(:), d(:)
    integer(8) :: ans = -100_8
    integer, allocatable :: list(:)
    integer :: i

    read *, n, m, q
    allocate(a(q), b(q), c(q), d(q))
    do i = 1, q
        read *, a(i), b(i), c(i), d(i)
        a(i) = a(i) - 1
        b(i) = b(i) - 1
    end do

    allocate(list(n))
    call dfs(list, 0)
    print *, ans

contains

    recursive subroutine dfs(list, k)
        integer, intent(inout) :: list(n)
        integer, intent(in) :: k
        integer(8) :: score
        integer :: next_num, start_num, i

        if (k == n) then
            score = 0_8
            do i = 1, q
                if (list(b(i)+1) - list(a(i)+1) == c(i)) then
                    score = score + d(i)
                end if
            end do
            if (score > ans) then
                ans = score
            end if
            return
        end if

        if (k == 0) then
            start_num = 1
        else
            start_num = list(k)
        end if

        do next_num = start_num, m
            list(k+1) = next_num
            call dfs(list, k+1)
        end do
    end subroutine dfs

end program main

Wait, but wait. The list array is passed as an argument to the recursive subroutine. In Fortran, when you pass an array to a subroutine, the subroutine receives it as an array with the same dimensions. So when modifying list(k+1) in the subroutine, the caller's list array is modified. However, during the loop over next_num, each iteration sets list(k+1) to next_num and then calls dfs. After the call returns, the next iteration overwrites list(k+1) again. So the backtracking is handled automatically. Because each call to dfs is modifying the same array, but each loop iteration resets the next element. This is correct.

Another thing to check: in the Java code, the list is built in order. The Fortran code's list is built in the same way. For example, when k=0, the next_num starts at 1, list(1) is set to next_num, and dfs is called with k=1. Then, in the next level, when k=1, start_num is list(1), which is the previous next_num.

Yes.

For each of these, check if the second element minus first equals 1. So sequences where the second element is first+1. For example, (1,2) gives 1, (2,3) gives 1. So ans would be 10 for (1,2) and (2,3), but (3,3) gives 0. So the maximum is 10.

So the code should generate all possible non-decreasing sequences of length n and compute the score.

- Handling the maximum ans correctly. The initial ans is -100, but if all scores are higher, it will be updated correctly.
